job_title: Registered Nurse in North Charleston, SC
pros: Team work, usually can pick days you want to work as long as you work two weekends per month
cons: Patient/nurse ratios are too high. Usually 7 high acuity patients for each nurse sometimes including the charge nurse, which means they are not able to help you out when needed bc they have a full load of patients also. Hard to transfer to other departments if wanting to move to another unit. Instead of hiring from within mostly they hire travelers to fill the gaps.

job_title: Registered Nurse in North Charleston, SC
pros: The people you work with care about their patients wellbeing, and will be friends for life.
cons: Short staffed, management doesn’t care, nor do the “suits” med/surg tele is often 7:1 Ed is of term greater then 4:1, icu likes to triple often. ED holds wait DAYS. hospital admin does nothing to assist when urgent patients come in needing beds causing departments to hold (such as stokes, MI, and trauma patients who went to OR). I would be terrified to know a loved one was a patient here knowing staff have no support, minimal resources, and are continually understaffed not giving my loved one the time and attention the need.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Charleston, SC
pros: family atmosphere, its hard work so everyone pretty much works together as a team to get the work done. great career opportunities-i have seen and experienced advancement from within. easy to approach and talk to uppers, however theyre hands must be tied because they really dont have the ability to lessen the pressures since its for profit im guessing. fair handling of issues and support from direct management when issues occur. inclusive atmosphere.
cons: hard work. heavy patient loads, increasing pressure on nursing and tech staff to satisfy patient satisfaction surveys which is difficult to keep patients happy when understaffed and overworked, no cost of living increases and not competitive with industry pay. relying on underpaying brand new graduating nurses so that skilled nurses can quit and not cause a vacuum.

job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Charleston, SC
pros: Decent benefits, during survey time you may get a T-shirt and free food
cons: Trident had a very toxic work culture. Employees experience bullying by upper management. Our Director would negatively discuss employees in front of others, be very passive-aggressive when communicating , would split staff, once placed her hand in my face, and told me to "shut up, shut my mouth". Nurses were asked to work in unethical patient-to-nursing ratios, while also having to fill in as techs, and do admissions and discharges, putting their licenses at risk. All the full-time case managers/social workers quit due to the toxic work environment and burnout. They were short-staffed for over a year and expected case managers/social workers to work an entire psych unit by themselves with no help doing collateral, admissions, discharges, hour-long groups, multiple discipline rounding, and linking patients with community resources. If a recreational therapist calls out or is on leave they expected the case manager/social worker to do their hour groups or they could split it with nursing. They did not bring in traveling workers, nor did they help and they expected you to do all of this in 8 hours with no overtime and you did not get any extra pay for doing the work of two. Many long-term employees left and continue to leave and went to HR for help before quitting but HR did absolutely nothing and it became clear HR is there to protect upper management. I didn't even receive an exit survey, more than likely because they already knew what my complaints would be. Also, there is no training or opportunities for CEU and due to lack of staffing, you are unable to take leave to attend workshops. They pay less than what is currently being offered in the community.

review_title: Low low low how low can you go?
job_title: CT Tech in North Charleston, SC
pros: Um...a paycheck and benefits. Free parking
cons: Salary structure is extremely low. This is one of the reasons they cannot keep staff. CT is a very stressful work environment. Yet they do nothing to make working in this counterintuitive . The pay scale for CT techs taps out at $34.50 . This is not competitive pay for a Experienced CT tech. The cost of living is high and the salary being low forces cT techs to work elsewhere. HCA executives make millions yet they do nothing to improve anything at the hospitals.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Charleston, SC

job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Charleston, SC
pros: Variation of patient types, coworkers
cons: It is all about the bottom line. Staff are underpaid and overworked. We are expected to do more with less. Staffing is downright scary and a 3:1 ratio is common in the ICU. The entire ICU turned over 100 staff members in the last 1.5 years and management turned a blind eye. Multiple false promises and no follow through. They do not care about the staff of the patients. Multiple events have occurred in patient harm and/or death and they do not change anything. It is all about the bonuses to upper management and admin. This facility has made me hate nursing as a whole.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Charleston, SC
pros: Apart from management, the staff at this hospital is amazing. I love my team, most of the doctors I work with are fantastic, my fellow nurses are phenomenal. I work cardiac so I love my patient population. My floor has a very team-oriented mentality and we are very supportive of each other.
cons: The hospital pays poorly, understaffing is a chronic issue. Often the charge nurse has a full load of patients. Our floor is the only floor that is usually staffed so our staff is pulled and floated to other units all the time, leaving us understaffed. We have 6 patients every shift which can be unsafe when patients are on cardiac drips.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in North Charleston, SC

review_title: The most uncaring medical environment I've ever seen - toward patients and most employees.
job_title: Patient Access Supervisor in North Charleston, SC
pros: Close to my residence and well, that's about it. Well, I have to put 20 Words on this. So, I guess it's close to some good food establishments.
cons:
The majority of the ER Nurses are rude and do not care about the patients. They talk about every patient that walks in the door and laugh about them over their radio/headset.  The clinical staff in the ER also have their own Soap Opera going on because they're all sleeping with one another and then hating one another the next day. It's nearly impossible to get a nurse to answer a call bell for a patients ER room. There are a few (maybe 5 or 6) ER nurses who are actually great at what they do and stay out of the drama. 

The nurses & other clinical staff in the ER treat other departments like trash. If I'm not mistaken, I believe all employees are supposed to follow the code of conduct and treat other employees with respect. Well, that's definitely not happening here. Don't bother voicing your concern in a professional manner and trying to improve departmental communication. You'll just get your hand slapped and it won't be confidential, as promised. 

Not sure where to even start with upper management. I've seen mediocre management in other Patient Access areas, but in the ER, support from your Manager and Director are basically non-existent. Don't bother asking them for advice or training on anything.  It doesn't help and you'll only get chewed out for not doing something a few weeks later anyway, even though they know you have no training on the matter at hand. 

I've worked in a few healthcare facilities previously and I've never seen such chaos and lack of compassion and care. I've worked places where I knew I was getting the best care available, but after working here, I tell my family to pass by this hospital if they ever need to bring me in.

If you interview here and leave with an amazing, promising feeling, just give it some time. Most things that seem too good to be true, usually are. Beware!!!!!!!
